title: Airlift
text:
An airlift is the organized delivery of <a href="Materiel">supplies</a> or <a href="personnel">personnel</a> primarily via <a href="military%20transport%20aircraft">military transport aircraft</a>.
Airlifting consists of two distinct types: strategic and tactical. Typically, strategic airlifting involves moving material long distances (such as across or off the continent or theater), whereas a tactical airlift focuses on deploying resources and material into a specific location with high precision.
Depending on the situation, airlifted supplies can be delivered by a variety of means. When the destination and surrounding <a href="airspace">airspace</a> is considered secure, the aircraft will land at an appropriate <a href="airport">airport</a> or <a href="airbase">airbase</a> to have its cargo unloaded on the ground. When landing the craft or distributing the supplies to a certain area from a <a href="landing%20zone">landing zone</a> by surface transportation is not an option, the cargo aircraft can drop them in mid-flight using <a href="parachute">parachute</a>s attached to the supply containers in question. When there is a broad area available where the intended receivers have control without fear of the enemy interfering with the collection and/or stealing the goods, the planes can maintain a normal flight <a href="altitude">altitude</a> and simply drop the supplies down and let them parachute to the ground. However, when the area is too small for this method, as with an isolated base, and/or is too dangerous to land in, a <a href="Low-altitude%20parachute-extraction%20system">Low-altitude parachute-extraction system</a> drop is used.
During disasters and other crises, airlifts are used to support or replace other transport methods to relieve beleaguered <a href="civilian">civilian</a> populations. Examples include the <a href="Berlin%20Airlift">Berlin Airlift</a>, to supply isolated <a href="West%20Berlin">West Berlin</a> with food and coal, the <a href="1990%20airlift%20of%20Indians%20from%20Kuwait">1990 Air India airlift</a> to rescue Indian citizens caught up in the <a href="Gulf%20War">Gulf War</a>, and the 1967–70 <a href="Biafran%20airlift">Biafran airlift</a> during the <a href="Nigerian%20Civil%20War">Nigerian Civil War</a>.
History.
In November 1915 the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Arm%C3%A9e%20de%20l%27Air%20%281909%E2%80%9342%29">French squadron "MF 99 S"</a>, equipped with <a href="Farman%20MF.11">Farman MF.11</a>, flew wounded soldiers from <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Serbia">Serbia</a> through <a href="Albanian%20Republic">Albania</a> to <a href="Corfu">Corfu</a>. This was the first <a href="medevac">medevac</a> operation in air history.
In April 1923 aircraft of the <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a>'s <a href="RAF%20Iraq%20Command">Iraq Command</a> flew 280 <a href="Sikhism">Sikh</a> troops from <a href="Kingarban">Kingarban</a> to <a href="Kirkuk">Kirkuk</a> in the first British air trooping operation. This operation was only conducted over a short-range and it was not until 1929 that the RAF conducted a long-range non-combat air evacuation of <a href="Embassy%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom%2C%20Kabul">British Embassy</a> staff from <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> to <a href="British%20Raj">India</a> using a <a href="Vickers%20Victoria">Vickers Victoria</a> during the <a href="Kabul%20airlift%20of%201928%E2%80%931929">Kabul airlift</a>.
The world's first long-range combat airlift took place from July to October 1936. <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi German</a> <a href="Luftwaffe">Luftwaffe</a> <a href="Junkers%20Ju%2052">Ju 52</a> and <a href="Fascist%20Italy%20%281922%E2%80%931943%29">Fascist Italian</a> <a href="Regia%20Aeronautica">Regia Aeronautica</a> <a href="Savoia-Marchetti%20SM.81">Savoia-Marchetti SM.81</a> were used by the <a href="Aviaci%C3%B3n%20Nacional">Spanish Nationalist Air Force</a> to transport <a href="Army%20of%20Africa%20%28Spain%29">Army of Africa</a> troops from <a href="Spanish%20protectorate%20in%20Morocco">Spanish Morocco</a> to the <a href="Peninsular%20Spain">Spanish mainland</a> at the <a href="Spanish%20coup%20of%20July%201936">beginning</a> of the <a href="Spanish%20Civil%20War">Spanish Civil War</a>.
Airlifts became practical during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> as aircraft became large and sophisticated enough to handle large cargo demands. The <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Air%20Forces">U.S. Army Air Force</a>'s <a href="Air%20Transport%20Command">Air Transport Command</a> began the largest and longest-sustained airlift of the war in May 1942, delivering more than half a million net tons of materiel from India to <a href="Free%20China%20%28Second%20Sino-Japanese%20War%29">Free China</a> over <a href="the%20Hump">the Hump</a> by November 1945. After many USAAF airmen were shot down in <a href="Territory%20of%20the%20Military%20Commander%20in%20Serbia">Nazi-occupied Serbia</a> during <a href="Operation%20Tidal%20Wave">Operation Tidal Wave</a>, the <a href="Fifteenth%20Air%20Force">U.S. Fifteenth Air Force</a> and the <a href="Office%20of%20Strategic%20Services">Office of Strategic Services</a> evacuated a number of them in <a href="Operation%20Halyard">Operation Halyard</a> with the assistance of <a href="Dra%C5%BEa%20Mihailovi%C4%87">Draža Mihailović</a>'s <a href="Chetniks">Chetnik</a> partisans. Additionally, at the end of World War II the USAAF and the RAF arranged humanitarian <a href="Airdrop">airdrops</a> to the <a href="Netherlands%20in%20World%20War%20II">Nazi-occupied Netherlands</a> through <a href="Operations%20Manna%20and%20Chowhound">Operations Manna and Chowhound</a> to alleviate the <a href="Dutch%20famine%20of%201944%E2%80%931945">Dutch famine of 1944-45</a>. However, airlifts still sometimes failed to provide sufficient cargo demands. Crucially, the Luftwaffe failed to keep the <a href="6th%20Army%20%28Wehrmacht%29">German Sixth Army</a> resupplied during its <a href="Operation%20Uranus">encirclement</a> by the <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a> at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Stalingrad">Battle of Stalingrad</a>, forcing its commander <a href="Friedrich%20Paulus">Friedrich Paulus</a> to surrender. After the successful relief of the <a href="Demyansk%20Pocket">Demyansk Pocket</a>, Chief of the <a href="Oberkommando%20der%20Luftwaffe">Oberkommando der Luftwaffe</a> <a href="Hermann%20G%C3%B6ring">Hermann Göring</a>'s assurance to <a href="Adolf%20Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> that the Luftwaffe could conduct an airlift was a key factor in his decision not to withdraw the Sixth Army from the city, and the German defeat in that battle marked the beginning of Nazi Germany's military collapse. 
The largest airlift was the <a href="Berlin%20Blockade">Berlin airlift</a>, lasting from June 1948 to September 1949, an international operation intended to thwart the blockading of <a href="West%20Berlin">West Berlin</a> by the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>. The airlift was arranged by the <a href="United%20States%20Air%20Force">U.S. Air Force</a>, the British Royal Air Force, the <a href="French%20Air%20and%20Space%20Force">French Air Force</a>, the <a href="Royal%20Canadian%20Air%20Force">Royal Canadian Air Force</a>, the <a href="Royal%20Australian%20Air%20Force">Royal Australian Air Force</a>, the <a href="Royal%20New%20Zealand%20Air%20Force">Royal New Zealand Air Force</a>, and the <a href="South%20African%20Air%20Force">South African Air Force</a> using <a href="Douglas%20C-47%20Skytrain">C-47 Skytrains</a>, <a href="Douglas%20C-54%20Skymaster">C-54 Skymasters</a>, <a href="Handley%20Page%20Halifax">Handley Page Haltons</a>, and <a href="Short%20Sunderland">Short Sunderlands</a>. Many Soviet and Western leaders alike initially assumed that an airlift to resupply West Berlin would fail because of the results of the Battle of Stalingrad. However, it instead succeeded and became an embarrassment for the Soviet Union, which ended the blockade. The blockade and the success of the airlift would be a major factor in the <a href="Cold%20War%20%281947%E2%80%931953%29">beginning of the Cold War</a> and the formation of the <a href="NATO">North Atlantic Treaty Organization</a>, the <a href="Western%20European%20Union">Western European Union</a>, and the <a href="West%20Germany">Federal Republic of Germany</a>. 
The <a href="Israeli%20Air%20Force">Israeli Air Force</a> and <a href="El%20Al">El Al</a> conducted a number of airlifts during the <a href="Jewish%20exodus%20from%20Arab%20and%20Muslim%20countries">Jewish exodus from Arab and Muslim countries</a> to <a href="Israel">Israel</a> after the <a href="1948%20Arab%E2%80%93Israeli%20War">1948 Arab–Israeli War</a>. In 1949 Israel evacuated 49,000 <a href="Yemenite%20Jews">Yemenite Jews</a> to <a href="Israel">Israel</a> via <a href="Operation%20Magic%20Carpet%20%28Yemen%29">Operation On Wings of Eagles</a>. In 1951 it carried out <a href="Operation%20Ezra%20and%20Nehemiah">Operation Ezra and Nehemiah</a> evacuating over 120,000 <a href="History%20of%20the%20Jews%20in%20Iraq">Jews</a> from <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Iraq">Iraq</a> to Israel via <a href="British%20Cyprus">British Cyprus</a>. The <a href="Israel%20Defense%20Forces">Israel Defense Forces</a> later evacuated over 8,000 <a href="Beta%20Israel">Beta Israel</a> refugees from <a href="Derg">Ethiopia</a> living in <a href="Refugee%20camp">refugee camps</a> in <a href="Democratic%20Republic%20of%20the%20Sudan">Sudan</a> through <a href="Operation%20Moses">Operation Moses</a>, <a href="Operation%20Joshua">Operation Joshua</a>, and <a href="Operation%20Solomon">Operation Solomon</a> during the <a href="1983%E2%80%931985%20famine%20in%20Ethiopia">Ethiopian famine</a> and <a href="Ethiopian%20Civil%20War">civil war</a>. 
The largest civilian airlift ever, the <a href="Biafran%20airlift">Biafran airlift</a>, was carried out by <a href="Protestantism">Protestant</a> and <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic</a> churches working together under the banner "Joint Church Aid" (JCA) to carry food to <a href="Biafra">Biafra</a>, during the <a href="Nigerian%20Civil%20War">Biafran secession war</a> from <a href="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> in 1967–70. This joint effort (which those involved used to call "Jesus Christ Airlines" as an inside joke from the initials JCA) is estimated to have saved more than a million lives in Biafra. Most airplanes departed from <a href="Portuguese%20S%C3%A3o%20Tom%C3%A9%20and%20Pr%C3%ADncipe">Portuguese São Tomé and Príncipe</a> to the bush landing strip of <a href="Uli%2C%20Nigeria">Uli</a>, the only operational "airport" in Biafra, which was made by enlarging a common road. Flights were made flying at night with all lights off and under near-total <a href="radio%20silence">radio silence</a> to avoid <a href="Nigerian%20Air%20Force">Nigerian Air Force</a> <a href="Mikoyan">MiG aircraft</a>. All the airplanes, crews, and logistics were paid, set up, and maintained by the joint church groups. JCA and their crews and aircraft (mostly aging multi prop airliners like <a href="Douglas%20DC-7">DC-7</a>'s, <a href="Lockheed%20Constellation">Lockheed Constellation</a> and <a href="Lockheed%20L-1049%20Super%20Constellation">Superconstellations</a>, <a href="Douglas%20DC-6">DC-6</a>'s, and <a href="Douglas%20DC-3">DC3</a>'s) kept flying into Biafra at the cost of many crews lives.
During the 1973 <a href="Yom%20Kippur%20War">Yom Kippur War</a>, the <a href="United%20States%20Air%20Force">U.S. Air Force</a> <a href="Military%20Airlift%20Command">Military Airlift Command</a> conducted <a href="Operation%20Nickel%20Grass">Operation Nickel Grass</a> to resupply Israel in the face of a coordinated surprise attack by <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> and <a href="Syria">Syria</a>. The airlift allowed Israel to begin a counteroffensive against the Arab states but caused the <a href="OPEC">Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries</a> to place an <a href="1973%20oil%20crisis">oil embargo</a> on the United States, beginning the <a href="1970s%20energy%20crisis">1970s energy crisis</a>.
During the 1974 <a href="Turkish%20invasion%20of%20Cyprus">Turkish invasion of Cyprus</a> the <a href="Hellenic%20Air%20Force">Hellenic Air Force</a> attempted to airlift commandos to <a href="Nicosia%20International%20Airport">Nicosia Airport</a> through <a href="Operation%20Niki">Operation Niki</a> but failed after the <a href="Nord%20Noratlas">Nord Noratlas</a> planes were shot down by <a href="friendly%20fire">friendly fire</a> from the <a href="Cypriot%20National%20Guard">Cypriot National Guard</a> after flying over <a href="RAF%20Akrotiri">RAF Akrotiri</a>. 
The largest civilian airlift in history was conducted by <a href="Air%20India">Air India</a> during the <a href="Gulf%20War">Gulf War</a>, which repatriated 176,000 Indian <a href="Migrant%20workers%20in%20Kuwait">migrant workers</a> stranded in <a href="Ba%27athist%20Iraq">Ba'athist Iraq</a> after the <a href="invasion%20of%20Kuwait">invasion of Kuwait</a>. <a href="India">India</a> has conducted other airlifts of migrant workers during Middle Eastern crises. The <a href="Indian%20Navy">Indian Navy</a> evacuated numerous Indian civilians from the <a href="2006%20Lebanon%20War">2006 Lebanon War</a> via <a href="Operation%20Sukoon">Operation Sukoon</a>, from the <a href="First%20Libyan%20Civil%20War">First Libyan Civil War</a> via <a href="Operation%20Safe%20Homecoming">Operation Safe Homecoming</a>, from the <a href="South%20Sudanese%20Civil%20War">South Sudanese Civil War</a> via <a href="Operation%20Sankat%20Mochan">Operation Sankat Mochan</a>, and from the <a href="Saudi%20Arabian-led%20intervention%20in%20Yemen">Saudi-Yemen War</a> in <a href="Operation%20Raahat">Operation Raahat</a>. The <a href="Pakistan%20Navy">Pakistan Navy</a> also <a href="Evacuation%20of%20Pakistani%20citizens%20during%20the%20Yemeni%20Civil%20War%20%282015%29">evacuated Pakistani nationals from Yemen via an airlift</a> during the Saudi intervention. The Indian Armed Forces also conducted an airlift to Nepal after the <a href="April%202015%20Nepal%20earthquake">2015 Nepal earthquake</a> through <a href="Operation%20Maitri">Operation Maitri</a>. 
During the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic%20in%20Hubei">outbreak</a> of the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> in <a href="Wuhan">Wuhan</a>, numerous air forces and civilian airlines arranged <a href="Evacuations%20related%20to%20the%20COVID-19%20pandemic">evacuation flights</a> from <a href="Wuhan%20Tianhe%20International%20Airport">Wuhan Tianhe International Airport</a>. 
During the <a href="Fall%20of%20Kabul%20%282021%29">fall of Kabul</a> at the end of the <a href="War%20in%20Afghanistan%20%282001%E2%80%932021%29">War in Afghanistan</a> after the <a href="Taliban">Taliban</a> captured most of <a href="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> in a <a href="2021%20Taliban%20offensive">2021 offensive</a> following the <a href="Withdrawal%20of%20United%20States%20troops%20from%20Afghanistan%20%282020%E2%80%932021%29">withdrawal of US and NATO forces</a>, <a href="2021%20evacuation%20from%20Afghanistan">foreign governments evacuated</a> hundreds of thousands of their citizens as well as at-risk Afghans from <a href="Hamid%20Karzai%20International%20Airport">Hamid Karzai International Airport</a>. As part of the <a href="United%20States%20Armed%20Forces">U.S. Armed Forces</a>' <a href="Operation%20Allies%20Refuge">Operation Allies Refuge</a>, U.S. Secretary of Defense <a href="Lloyd%20Austin">Lloyd Austin</a> requisitioned U.S. airliners through the <a href="Civil%20Reserve%20Air%20Fleet">Civil Reserve Air Fleet</a> to assist the <a href="United%20States%20Transportation%20Command">U.S. Transportation Command</a>. The <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20Defense">U.S. Department of Defense</a> later claimed to have evacuated 122,000 people, including <a href="Citizenship%20of%20the%20United%20States">U.S. citizens</a> and Afghan <a href="Special%20Immigrant%20Visa">Special Immigrant Visa</a> applicants. Other airlifts included the <a href="British%20Armed%20Forces">British Armed Forces</a>' <a href="Operation%20Pitting">Operation Pitting</a>, the <a href="Canadian%20Armed%20Forces">Canadian Armed Forces</a>' <a href="Operation%20AEGIS">Operation AEGIS</a>, and the <a href="Indian%20Armed%20Forces">Indian Armed Forces</a>' <a href="Operation%20Devi%20Shakti">Operation Devi Shakti</a>.
Strategic airlift.
Strategic airlift is the use of <a href="military%20transport%20aircraft">military transport aircraft</a> to transport <a href="materiel">materiel</a>, <a href="weapon">weapon</a>ry, or <a href="personnel">personnel</a> over long distances. Typically, this involves airlifting the required items between two airbases that are not in the same vicinity. This allows <a href="commander">commander</a>s to bring items into a combat theater from a point on the other side of the planet, if necessary. Aircraft which perform this role are considered strategic airlifters. This contrasts with tactical airlifters, such as the <a href="C-130%20Hercules">C-130 Hercules</a> and <a href="Transall%20C-160">Transall C-160</a>, which can normally only move supplies within a given <a href="theater%20of%20operations">theater of operations</a>.

With present technology, it is impossible to shift a substantial mechanised force, particularly <a href="tank">tank</a>s, by air. This difficulty has prompted investment in lighter armoured fighting vehicles (such as the <a href="Stryker">Stryker</a>), as well as some preliminary research into alternative airlift technologies such as <a href="ground%20effect%20vehicles">ground effect vehicles</a> and <a href="airship">airship</a>s. Civilian aircraft are also commonly used for transportation. For some civilian airlines, such as <a href="Volga-Dnepr%20Airlines%23Military%20missions">Volga-Dnepr Airlines</a>, military contracts account for a large portion of their income.
Tactical airlift.
Tactical airlift is a <a href="military">military</a> term for the airborne transportation of supplies and equipment "within" a <a href="theater%20%28warfare%29">theatre of operations</a> (in contrast to strategic airlift). Aircraft that perform this role are referred to as tactical airlifters. These are typically <a href="turboprop">turboprop</a> aircraft and feature short landing and take-off distances and low-pressure tires allowing operations from small or poorly prepared airstrips. While they lack the speed and range of strategic airlifters (which are typically <a href="jet%20engine">jet</a>-powered), these capabilities are invaluable within war zones. Larger <a href="helicopter">helicopter</a>s such as the <a href="CH-47%20Chinook">CH-47 Chinook</a> and <a href="Mil%20Mi-26">Mil Mi-26</a> can also be used to airlift men and equipment. Helicopters have the advantage that they do not require a landing strip and that equipment can often be suspended below the aircraft allowing it to be delivered without landing but are fuel inefficient and thus typically have limited range. Hybrid aircraft such as the <a href="Bell%20Boeing%20V-22%20Osprey">Bell Boeing V-22 Osprey</a> also exist which attempt to combine <a href="VTOL">VTOL</a> flight with greater range and speed.
Tactical airlift aircraft are designed to be maneuverable, allowing the low-altitude flight to avoid detection by radar and for the <a href="airdrop">airdrop</a>ping of supplies. Most are fitted with <a href="defensive%20aids%20system">defensive aids system</a>s to protect them from attack by <a href="surface-to-air%20missile">surface-to-air missile</a>s.
The earliest Soviet tactical airlift occurred in 1929, in which forty men of the <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a> were airlifted to the town of <a href="Garm%2C%20Tajikistan">Garm</a>, <a href="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a> (then the <a href="Tajik%20Autonomous%20Soviet%20Socialist%20Republic">Tajik Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic</a>) to repel an attacking force of <a href="Basmachi%20movement">Basmachi</a> rebels under <a href="Faizal%20Maksum">Fuzail Maksum</a>.
